UART magic number for handle verification.

#define AM_HAL_MAGIC_UART   0xEA9E06
 
#define AM_HAL_UART_CHK_HANDLE(h)
 

Baudrate to byte-time in microseconds with a little extra margin.

#define ONE_BYTE_US(baudrate)   (12000000/(baudrate))
 
#define ONE_BYTE_DELAY(handle)    am_hal_flash_delay(FLASH_CYCLES_US(ONE_BYTE_US((handle)->ui32BaudRate)))

UART Flag Register

Macro definitions for UART Flag Register Bits.

They may be used with the am_hal_uart_flags_get() function.

#define AM_HAL_UART_FR_TX_EMPTY   (_VAL2FLD(UART0_FR_TXFE, UART0_FR_TXFE_XMTFIFO_EMPTY))
 
#define AM_HAL_UART_FR_RX_FULL   (_VAL2FLD(UART0_FR_RXFF, UART0_FR_RXFF_RCVFIFO_FULL))
 
#define AM_HAL_UART_FR_TX_FULL   (_VAL2FLD(UART0_FR_TXFF, UART0_FR_TXFF_XMTFIFO_FULL))

Function Documentation

◆ am_hal_uart_configure()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_configure ( void *  pHandle,
const am_hal_uart_config_t *  psConfig 
)

Used to configure basic UART settings.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
psConfig- A structure of UART configuration options.

This function takes the options from an am_hal_uart_config_t structure, and applies them to the UART referred to by pHandle.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_control()

eControl

◆ am_hal_uart_deinitialize()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_deinitialize ( void *  pHandle)

Deinitialize the UART interface.

Parameters
pHandle- A previously initialized UART handle.

This function effectively disables future calls to interact with the UART refered to by pHandle. The user may call this function if UART operation is no longer desired.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_fifo_read()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_fifo_read ( void *  pHandle,
uint8_t *  pui8Data,
uint32_t  ui32NumBytes,
uint32_t *  pui32NumBytesRead 
)

Read the UART FIFO directly.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pui8Data- A pointer where the UART data should be written.
ui32NumBytes- The number of bytes to transfer.
pui32NumBytesRead- The number of bytes actually transferred.

This function reads the UART FIFO directly, and writes the resulting bytes to pui8Data. Since the UART FIFO hardware has no direct size indicator, the caller can only specify the maximum number of bytes they can handle. This function will try to read as many bytes as possible. At the end of the transfer, the number of bytes actually transferred will be written to the pui32NumBytesRead parameter.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART error.

◆ am_hal_uart_fifo_write()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_fifo_write ( void *  pHandle,
uint8_t *  pui8Data,
uint32_t  ui32NumBytes,
uint32_t *  pui32NumBytesWritten 
)

Write the UART FIFO directly.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pui8Data- A pointer where the UART data should be written.
ui32NumBytes- The number of bytes to transfer.
pui32NumBytesWritten- The number of bytes actually transferred.

This function reads from pui8Data, and writes the requested number of bytes directly to the UART FIFO. Since the UART FIFO hardware has no register to tell us how much free space it has, the caller can only specify the number of bytes they would like to send. This function will try to write as many bytes as possible up to the requested number. At the end of the transfer, the number of bytes actually transferred will be written to the pui32NumBytesWritten parameter.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART error.

◆ am_hal_uart_flags_get()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_flags_get ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t *  pui32Flags 
)

Read the UART flags.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pui32Flags- The destination pointer for the UART flags.

The UART hardware provides some information about the state of the physical interface at all times. This function provides a way to read that data directly. Below is a list of all possible UART flags.

These correspond directly to the bits in the UART_FR register.

AM_HAL_UART_FR_TX_EMPTY
AM_HAL_UART_FR_RX_FULL
AM_HAL_UART_FR_TX_FULL
AM_HAL_UART_FR_RX_EMPTY
AM_HAL_UART_FR_BUSY
AM_HAL_UART_FR_DCD_DETECTED
AM_HAL_UART_FR_DSR_READY
AM_HAL_UART_FR_CTS

◆ am_hal_uart_interrupt_disable()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_interrupt_disable ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32IntMask 
)

Disable interrupts.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
ui32IntMask- The bitmask of interrupts to disable.

This function disables the UART interrupt(s) given by ui32IntMask. If multiple interrupts need to be disabled, they can be OR'ed together.

Note
This function need not be called for UART FIFO interrupts if the UART buffer service provided by am_hal_uart_buffer_configure() and am_hal_uart_interrupt_service() is already in use. Non-FIFO-related interrupts do require the use of this function.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_UART_INT_OVER_RUN
AM_HAL_UART_INT_BREAK_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_PARITY_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_FRAME_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX_TMOUT
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DSRM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DCDM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_CTSM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TXCMP
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

)

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.

This function enables the UART interrupt(s) given by ui32IntMask. If multiple interrupts are desired, they can be OR'ed together.

Note
This function need not be called for UART FIFO interrupts if the UART buffer service provided by am_hal_uart_buffer_configure() and am_hal_uart_interrupt_service() is already in use. Non-FIFO-related interrupts do require the use of this function.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_UART_INT_OVER_RUN

◆ am_hal_uart_interrupt_enable_get()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_interrupt_enable_get ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t *  pui32IntMask 
)

Check to see which interrupts are enabled.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pui32IntMask- The current set of interrupt enable bits (all bits OR'ed together)

This function checks the UART Interrupt Enable Register to see which UART interrupts are currently enabled. The result will be an interrupt mask with one bit set for each of the currently enabled UART interrupts.

The full set of UART interrupt bits is given by the list below:

AM_HAL_UART_INT_OVER_RUN
AM_HAL_UART_INT_BREAK_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_PARITY_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_FRAME_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX_TMOUT
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DSRM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DCDM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_CTSM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TXCMP
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_interrupt_service()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_interrupt_service ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t  ui32Status,
uint32_t *  pui32UartTxIdle 
)

This function handles the UART buffers during UART interrupts.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
ui32Status- The interrupt status at the time of ISR entry.
pui32UartTxIdle- Can be used to store the UART idle status.

The main purpose of this function is to manage the UART buffer system. Any buffers configured by am_hal_uart_buffer_configure will be managed by this service routine. Data queued for transmit will be added to the UART TX FIFO as space allows, and data stored in the UART RX FIFO will be copied out and stored in the RX buffer. This function will skip this transfer for any buffer that has not been configured.

In addition, this function can be used to alert the caller when the UART becomes idle via the optional pui32UartTxIdle argument. This function will set this variable any time it completes its operation and the UART TX channel is no longer in use (including both the FIFO and any configured buffer). To make sure this happens as early as possible, the user may enable the UART_TXCMP interrupt as shown below.

For RTOS-enabled cases, this function does not necessarily need to be called inside the actual ISR for the UART, but it should be called promptly in response to the receipt of a UART TX, RX, or RX timeout interrupt. If the service routine is not called quickly enough, the caller risks an RX FIFO overflow (data can be lost here), or a TX FIFO underflow (usually not harmful).

void
am_uart_isr(void)
{
//
// Service the FIFOs as necessary, and clear the interrupts.
//
uint32_t ui32Status;
uint32_t ui32UartIdle;
am_hal_uart_interrupt_status_get(UART, &ui32Status, true);
am_hal_uart_interrupt_clear(UART, ui32Status);
am_hal_uart_interrupt_service(UART, ui32Status, &ui32UartIdle);
ui32TXDoneFlag = ui32UartIdle;
}
int
main(void)
{
...
// Initialize, power up, and configure the UART.
am_hal_uart_initialize(0, &UART);
am_hal_uart_power_control(UART, AM_HAL_SYSCTRL_WAKE, false);
am_hal_uart_configure(UART, &sUartConfig);
...
// Enable the UART0 interrupt vector.
am_hal_uart_interrupt_enable(UART, AM_REG_UART_IER_TXCMPMIM_M);
am_hal_interrupt_enable(AM_HAL_INTERRUPT_UART0);
am_hal_interrupt_master_enable();
}

uint32_t am_hal_interrupt_master_enable(void)

◆ am_hal_uart_interrupt_status_get()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_interrupt_status_get ( void *  pHandle,
uint32_t *  pui32Status,
bool  bEnabledOnly 
)

Read interrupt status.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pui32Status- The returned interrupt status (all bits OR'ed together)
bEnabledOnly- determines whether to read interrupts that were not enabled.

This function reads the status the UART interrupt(s) if bEnabled is true, it will only return the status of the enabled interrupts. Otherwise, it will return the status of all interrupts, enabled or disabled.

The full list of interrupts is given by the following:

AM_HAL_UART_INT_OVER_RUN
AM_HAL_UART_INT_BREAK_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_PARITY_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_FRAME_ERR
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX_TMOUT
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_RX
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DSRM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_DCDM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_CTSM
AM_HAL_UART_INT_TXCMP
Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_power_control()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_power_control ( void *  pHandle,
am_hal_sysctrl_power_state_e  ePowerState,
bool  bRetainState 
)

Change the power state of the UART module.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
ePowerState- the desired power state of the UART.
bRetainState- A flag to ask the HAL to save UART registers.

This function can be used to switch the power to the UART on or off. If bRetainState is true during a powerdown operation, it will store the UART configuration registers to SRAM, so it can restore them on power-up.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_transfer()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_transfer ( void *  pHandle,
const am_hal_uart_transfer_t *  pTransfer 
)

Transfer data through the UART interface.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.
pTransfer- A structure describing the operation.

This function executes a transaction as described by the am_hal_uart_transfer_t structure. It can either read or write, and it will take advantage of any buffer space provided by the am_hal_uart_configure() function.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.

◆ am_hal_uart_tx_flush()

uint32_t am_hal_uart_tx_flush ( void *  pHandle)

Wait for the UART TX to become idle.

Parameters
pHandle- The handle for the UART to operate on.

This function waits (polling) for all data in the UART TX FIFO and UART TX buffer (if configured) to be fully sent on the physical UART interface. This is not the most power-efficient way to wait for UART idle, but it can be useful in simpler applications, or where power-efficiency is less important.

Once this function returns, the UART can be safely disabled without interfering with any previous transmissions.

For a more power-efficient way to shut down the UART, check the am_hal_uart_interrupt_service() function.

Returns
AM_HAL_STATUS_SUCCESS or applicable UART errors.
